DataElement.preferredName: Measurable Non-Measurable Neoplasm Assessment Lesion Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The anatomic site of a non/measureable lesion within the patient.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Capable of being measured._Not possible to be measured._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Capable of being measured.:Not possible to be measured.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: Capable of being measured.
Not possible to be measured.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An abnormal enlargement of an organ, particularly an organ of the abdominal cavity.: Of, or related to, the abdomen.

Concepts.definition: An abnormal enlargement of an organ, particularly an organ of the abdominal cavity.
Of, or related to, the abdomen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum.

Concepts.definition: The accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity, which may be serous, hemorrhagic, or the result of tumor metastasis to the peritoneum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic process that contains a single or multiple sac-like spaces.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic process that contains a single or multiple sac-like spaces.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the breast. Representative examples of non-neoplastic disorders include fibrocystic disease, gynecomastia, and mastitis. Representative examples of neoplastic disorders include fibroadenoma, lobular neoplasia, carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.: Relating to inflammation.

Concepts.definition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the breast. Representative examples of non-neoplastic disorders include fibrocystic disease, gynecomastia, and mastitis. Representative examples of neoplastic disorders include fibroadenoma, lobular neoplasia, carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.
Relating to inflammation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread from its original site to the two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread from its original site to the two innermost layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

Concepts.definition: Earlier in time or order.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.: Extensive infiltration of the lymphatic vessels by cancer cells, resulting in widespread cancer dissemination.  The lymphatic vessels appear as palpable, cord-like structures, especially in skin areas overlying the carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

Extensive infiltration of the lymphatic vessels by cancer cells, resulting in widespread cancer dissemination.  The lymphatic vessels appear as palpable, cord-like structures, especially in skin areas overlying the carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A primary or metastatic malignant tumor involving the lymph node.  Lymphomas and metastatic carcinomas are representative examples. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A primary or metastatic malignant tumor involving the lymph node.  Lymphomas and metastatic carcinomas are representative examples.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fluid collection within the pericardial sac, usually due to inflammation.: Of or pertaining to the pleura.

Concepts.definition: Fluid collection within the pericardial sac, usually due to inflammation.
Of or pertaining to the pleura.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
